Cinema Resources, NYU Cinema Studies Department                                                                                                                                                                               Return to PhD Students     Jaap Verheul                                      Jaap Verheul ( jcv239@nyu.edu ) is a PhD Candidate in Cinema Studies (ABD) at New York University, where his dissertation focuses on popular European cinema as it chronicles the dynamics between European audiovisual policy and regional and national filmmaking in the European Union today. He received his BA in Media and Culture from the University of Amsterdam (2007) and his MA in Cinema Studies from New York University (2009).   Jaap has written on the representation of trauma and memory in Sidney Lumets The Pawnbroker (2007), on the fascist aesthetics in the work of Busby Berkeley (2009), and on the conceptualization of multiculturalism in the popular television show Lost (2010). He further explored his interest in cinematic violence in an essay on the relationship between paranoia and preemptive violence in the television series 24 , which he wrote for an anthology on Hollywood Politics (2010). Furthermore, for Brooklyn Rail (2013), Jaap has analyzed the representation of the European bourgeoisie in the work of Austrian filmmaker Michael Haneke. Finally, for an upcoming anthology on Lasting Stars (2014), he will publish an essay on the fluctuating stardoms of George Lazenby and James Bond, while his forthcoming publication on Dutch language cinema (2015) examines the linguistic barrier that obstructs cinematic exchange between Flanders (Belgium) and the Netherlands.   As an instructor and teaching assistant at New York University, Jaap has taught courses on film theory, black American cinema, James Bond, and filmmaking in Hollywood from the 1960s onward. He is a recipient of New York Universitys Council for Media and Culture Dissertation and Thesis Grant," and in the Spring of 2015, he will be a Research Fellow at Remarque Institute at the cole normale suprieure in Paris, France.

Cinema Resources, NYU Cinema Studies Department                                                                                                                                                                               Return to PhD Students     Jaap Verheul                                      Jaap Verheul ( jcv239@nyu.edu ) is a PhD Candidate in Cinema Studies (ABD) at New York University, where his dissertation focuses on popular European cinema as it chronicles the dynamics between European audiovisual policy and regional and national filmmaking in the European Union today. He received his BA in Media and Culture from the University of Amsterdam (2007) and his MA in Cinema Studies from New York University (2009).   Jaap has written on the representation of trauma and memory in Sidney Lumets The Pawnbroker (2007), on the fascist aesthetics in the work of Busby Berkeley (2009), and on the conceptualization of multiculturalism in the popular television show Lost (2010). He further explored his interest in cinematic violence in an essay on the relationship between paranoia and preemptive violence in the television series 24 , which he wrote for an anthology on Hollywood Politics (2010). Furthermore, for Brooklyn Rail (2013), Jaap has analyzed the representation of the European bourgeoisie in the work of Austrian filmmaker Michael Haneke. Finally, for an upcoming anthology on Lasting Stars (2014), he will publish an essay on the fluctuating stardoms of George Lazenby and James Bond, while his forthcoming publication on Dutch language cinema (2015) examines the linguistic barrier that obstructs cinematic exchange between Flanders (Belgium) and the Netherlands.   As an instructor and teaching assistant at New York University, Jaap has taught courses on film theory, black American cinema, James Bond, and filmmaking in Hollywood from the 1960s onward. He is a recipient of New York Universitys Council for Media and Culture Dissertation and Thesis Grant," and in the Spring of 2015, he will be a Research Fellow at Remarque Institute at the cole normale suprieure in Paris, France.

European Unity / National Diversion: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Department of Cinema Studies _Copy Undergraduate Graduate MIAP Home Dual BA/MA Program Asian Film and Media Initiative (AFMI) Certificate in Culture and Media Financial Aid and Scholarships Course Offerings News & Events Faculty & Administration Alumni Cinema Resources Blog Announcements  home > Cinema Studies        European Unity / National Diversion - A Department of Cinema Studies Colloquium  Event Date and Time:    April 3, 2013 6:15pm    Location:    Department of Cinema Studies, Michelson Theater 721 Broadway, 6th Floor New York, NY 10003    This colloquium addresses questions of national identity within the changing cultural and sociopolitical context of Europe, investigating recent developments in European film culture and policymaking. Considering questions of (self-)representation, as well as issues relating to disjunctions and ruptures within a united continent, the panel looks at the varied ways in which the national can be considered in contemporary European filmmaking.    This event is free and open to the public.    Participants    Jaap Verheul    Born in the Netherlands, raised in Belgium, and educated in both of those countries as well as the United States, Jaap Verheul is a PhD Candidate in Cinema Studies at New York University, where his dissertation focuses on popular European Cinema as it chronicles the dynamics of regional and national filmmaking in the European Union today. He received his BA in Media and Culture from the University of Amsterdam (2007) and his MA in Cinema Studies from New York University (2009). Jaap is a frequent contributor to the Belgian film journal CineMagie , for which he has written on the representation of trauma and memory in Sidney Lumet’s The Pawnbroker (2007); on the fascist aesthetics in the work of Busby Berkeley (2009), and on the conceptualization of multiculturalism in the television show Lost (2010). In addition, he has also published an essay on the relationship between paranoia and preemptive violence in the television show 24 , written for an anthology on Hollywood Politics (2010), and for Brooklyn Rail on the representation of the European bourgeoisie in the oeuvre of Michael Haneke (2013).    Jaap’s presentation will address the reassertion of local identity in the wake of European unification. He will analyze the proliferation of the “folk film,” which is targeted at a regional or national market and generates popular but local public interest through its articulation of culturally specific folklore. This presentation will focus on the work of the popular French filmmaker Dany Boon in particular. In BIENVENUE CHEZ LES CH’TIS (France: Dany Boon, 2008), Boon communicates a northern French regional identity through the story of a postal office manager in the romanticized south of France who is relocated to the northern town of Bergues, which turns out not to be as depressing as he had feared. In like manner, his RIEN À DÉCLARER (France: Dany Boon, 2010) concerns a farcical comedy about a Belgian and a French police officer who are forced to work together to guard the Franco-Belgian border. This presentation will argue that the minimal exportability and translatability of these folk films signify the limits of a unified European film-market.    Linnéa Hussein    Born in Germany to German-Iraqi parents, Linnéa Hussein moved to the U.K. upon finishing high school where she worked on her B.A. (honours) in film and American studies from the University of East Anglia. She received her Masters degree in film studies from Columbia University in 2011, where she wrote her thesis on The Sick on Display: Aberrantification of Patients and Exploitations of the Body in London Missionary Society Films . Before she started her Ph.D. at New York University, she worked for Just Vision and The Jacob Burns Film Center. Her works have appeared in The New Inquiry as well as in The Funambulist . Her research interests include early non-fiction imaginations of colonialisms, as well as the intersection between medical cameras and documentary theory.    In the years following World War II, the German concept of “Vergangenheitsbewältigung,” designating the processes of dealing with the past, was taken from its original personal-trauma related meaning and applied to the nation in shambles. Policies in all sectors were created in order to leave the trauma of the war behind and to raise a new generation of Germans, conscious of the past and yet moving towards building a new economy and a new nation state. A European identity as promoted by European Unity, came to rescue what was left of a shirked national identity. By looking at the formation of historical knowledge as channeled through high school history textbooks in Germany, Linnéa will retrace what lies at the roots of the representation of Vergangenheitsbewältigung in contemporary German cinema post 2000, in particular Ein Spezialist (Sivan, 1999), Eichmann (Young, 2007), and Hannah Arendt (von Trotta, 2013). She will examine and explore concepts such as collective guilt and collective responsibility to ask questions concerning generational differences to national identity claims in the German as well as in the wider European context.    Sonja Simonyi    Sonja Simonyi is a PhD student in Cinema Studies at New York University. Her dissertation focuses on the appropriation of the Western in socialist Eastern Europe, contextualizing this phenomenon within the broader framework of national and regional identity. Born in Hungary, she spent a significant portion of her life in Belgium, where she received her BA from the Université Libre de Bruxelles. Before coming to NYU, Sonja completed her MA at American University and was a research fellow at the National Gallery of Art in Washington DC, where she curated the extensive film program Modernity and Tradition: Film in interwar Central Europe . Her essay on 1970s Hungarian Westerns will be included in a forthcoming volume on the international manifestations of the genre.    Sonja considers the ways in which the east/west division of Europe continues to pervade representations of the continent in the post-Cold War era. In particular, her presentation looks at how contemporary cinematic narratives give shape to this seemingly fading, yet economically, politically and culturally still significant divide. The thematic oppositions of inclusion and exclusion, social alienation and integration in both “east” and “west” are examined through the 2008 Austrian film Import / Export (Ulrich Seidl), which engages the two European spheres through a fictional narrative of bidirectional migration between the Ukraine and Austria. Considering the representation of the different geographical and diverging socio-cultural realms the film portrays, and the various processes of import and export the characters engage in, provides constructive frameworks through which to address questions of the regional and the national within the context of contemporary European society.
